title: 110_s3376
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States Olympic Committee Paralympic Program Act of 2008". Congress enacted the Olympic and Amateur Sports Act Amendments of 1998 to support amateur athletic programs for athletes with disabilities. The United States Olympic Committee manages the Paralympic Program for physically disabled athletes. In 2005, a memorandum of understanding was signed between the Committee and the Secretary. The Paralympic Program, managed by the United States Olympic Committee, aims to provide special training and rehabilitation to disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces to improve their quality of life and reduce secondary medical conditions. The Paralympic Program aims to expand to provide rehabilitative services through sports to disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces, promoting their life-long health and developing a system to support disabled sports at all levels. To support local organizations in providing Paralympic sports training to disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces in their communities. Additionally, to assist the United States Olympic Committee in increasing the participation of disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces in sports for rehabilitation. The Department of Veterans Affairs will provide assistance to the United States Olympic Committee Paralympic program. The Department of Veterans Affairs will provide grants to the United States Olympic Committee for the Paralympic Program for disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces. The Committee must allow oversight by the Secretary for the proper use of grant funds. An application describing the program is required before receiving a grant. The Committee must submit an application to the Secretary detailing the activities and measurable goals to be achieved with grant funds. Partnerships with national organizations experienced in training disabled athletes must be included, such as Disabled Sports USA and Paralyzed Veterans of America. The United States Olympic Committee partners with national organizations to provide funding for sport programs promoting physical activity, games, and competition for disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces. The grant funds are used to recruit, support, and implement activities approved by the Secretary. The United States Olympic Committee partners with national organizations to provide funding for sport programs promoting physical activity, games, and competition for disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces. These programs offer instruction, participation, and competition in Paralympic sports, training and technical assistance, and coordination of Paralympic classification of athletes. Services may also be provided for individuals with disabilities who are not veterans or members of the Armed Forces, but funds cannot be used to support those individuals. The program funded by the United States Olympic Committee supports sport programs for disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces, including athlete assessment, training techniques, program development, medical support, and equipment. Grants may cover administrative expenses up to ten percent. The Secretary is required to conduct an outreach campaign to inform eligible veterans and separating individuals. The Secretary is mandated to conduct an outreach campaign to inform eligible veterans and separating members of the Armed Forces with physical disabilities about the Paralympic Program. The Department is authorized $8,000,000 annually for this program, ensuring access to facilities for disabled participants without affecting other veteran assistance. Funds appropriated for this section must not be mixed with other Department funds. These funds are limited to supporting disabled veterans and members of the Armed Forces. A new item is added to the table of sections in the chapter. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must wait for a memorandum of understanding with the United States Olympic Committee before awarding a grant for the Paralympic Program. The agreement must be finalized within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The Office of National Veterans Sports Programs and Special Events is established within the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Director is responsible for organizing programs and events, sponsoring them, and promoting participation by disabled veterans. The Office of National Veterans Sports Programs and Special Events, established within the Department of Veterans Affairs, promotes participation by disabled veterans in approved sports programs and events. The Director may provide a monthly assistance allowance to a veteran with a disability invited by the United States Olympic Committee to compete. The Office of National Veterans Sports Programs and Special Events, established within the Department of Veterans Affairs, promotes participation by disabled veterans in approved sports programs and events. The Director may provide a monthly assistance allowance to a veteran with a disability invited by the United States Olympic Committee to compete for a slot on the Paralympic Team or residing at a training center. The assistance amount is equivalent to the monthly subsistence allowance under chapter 31, and is in addition to any other available assistance. $2,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2009 and beyond. The section does not limit current disabled sports and special events supported by the Department. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the chapter. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs directs the Under Secretary for Health to provide medical staff for veterans to participate in sporting events, including the Paralympic Program, without using personal leave. Support for similar activities as determined appropriate by the Secretary is also required.
